page.title: 08HALL PLACE, BEXLEYHEATH
page.content:
This area is chiefly open space, with a small housing content. The major feature of the area is Hall Place and its grounds.
Hall Place dates from 1540, with some evidence of earlier houses from the 13th. Century onwards. As it stands, it is part-Tudor, part-Jacobean, stone and brick together with a Tudor built brick barn.
Topiary; a herb garden; sunken garden and rockery; rose beds and lawns together with greenhouses; all of which are open for public viewing all year round.
The remaining open space is used as sports grounds and open grassland, with the River Cray forming its southerly border.
